captions.text:
A proof has been announced of a
unsolved, so far, conjecture
called the abc Conjecture.

If this proof is right, then
it's going to be news on the

scale of Fermat's last theorem
was in the '90s, which was
this big unsolved problem.
And was this huge event.
So it's really exciting.

We don't know if this proof is
right yet, so a Japanese

mathematician called Mochizuki
has released these papers, and

altogether, it's
500 pages long.

He's been working on this
for a very long time.

He's come up with his own theory
of maths-- a whole new
body of maths--

and he's called it
interuniversal geometry.
I know nothing about that.
Very few people do.

Even the experts don't know much
about this at the moment.

So it's going to take a very
long time to make sure if the

proof is right, because they're
going to have to learn

this whole new theory
of mathematics.

So the abc Conjecture involves
the most simple formula you
can think of.
It's this--
a plus b equals c.

It doesn't get much
easier than that.

And that's where it gets
its name from.

The rules are, these are whole
numbers, and they don't share
any factors.

So that means if I can divide
a by 2, then I'm not allowed
to divide b by 2.

Or if I could divide a by 3,
then b is not allowed to be
divisible by three.

They're not allowed to share
any factors like that.

All right, let's try an
example that works.
1,024 plus 81 equals 1,105.

Right, now let's just check they
don't share any factors.

In fact, I've picked
these on purpose.

This one is 2 to the power of
10, and this one is 3 to the
power of 4.

So they don't share
any factors there.

Oh, and this one, I'll do the
same, is 5 times 13 times 17.

Now, this is what I want
you to notice.

On the left hand side, you've
got lots of prime numbers.

We've got all 10 of them over
here, and another four.
Loads of them over here.

On the right hand side, you only
have three, and this is

what you tend to see
most of the time.
This is what's normal.

If you get lots of primes on the
left, you only get a few
on the right hand side.

So this is what the conjecture
is about.

I want to show you one where
it doesn't work.
3 plus 125.
That's equal to 128.

Let's just check they don't
share any factors then-- well,

that's 3, this is 5 cubed,
and this, 128, is 2
the power of 7.

Now, this one is not like the
first one I showed you.

You've only got a few primes
on the left, but we've got
loads more on a right.

So you've got more on the right
than you do on the left.
That's unusual.
That's weird.

So rather than not working, like
I said earlier, it's the
unusual example.
These don't happen so often.

So the technical way to
say this is this.
Times those primes together.
So I'm going to do that.

So 2 times 3 times 5 times
13 times 17, and
that equals to 13,260.

It's a big number, and it's
bigger than the right hand
side, which was this.
That's what normally happens.

OK, so if you do this, you
get a bigger number.

I'm going to show you this one
that I said was unusual.
If we do the same thing--

3 times 5 times 2, that's
equal to 30, and that's
smaller than 128.
So that's the difference.
So this is unusual.

This is much smaller than
the right hand side.

This number, when you multiply
the primes together, is called
the radical of ABC.

It's called the radical because
it is [INAUDIBLE].

The abc Conjecture
is the radical--

which I told you how to work
out, that's this--

the radical of abc is bigger
than the right hand side.
I said that was c.
That's what you get normally.

In fact, the conjecture
is more than that.

It talks about the powers
of that, too.

But there are exceptions, and
these are the exceptions.

When k equals 1-- that's
the power is 1--

there are infinitely many
exceptions just like the one
I've just shown you there.

Infinitely many, even though I
said these were the rare ones,

the unusual ones, there are
infinitely many of them.

But if you take a power bigger
than 1, even if it's only a

little bit bigger, even if it's
like a power of 1.00001--
tiny, tiny little bit bigger--

if it's bigger than 1, then
you get finitely many
exceptions.

And this is a little bit
surprising, because, yes, if

it's just a little bit bigger
than 1, you get finitely many
exceptions.
You could count them off.
You could write them down.

You could say, here are all the
exceptions for this power.
And that's unusual.
That's unexpected.
Now, this is the conjecture.
It's very abstract.
It's very pure.

This was made in the '80s,
this conjecture.

But if this can be proven, what
it's going to do is it's

going to prove a whole bunch
of other stuff at a stroke.
And that's why it's big news.

Originally, they thought that
Fermat's last theorem, which I

talked about being solved in
the '90s, they thought this
was the way to solve it.

Because there is a way that, if
you can solve this, you can

solve a version of Fermat's
last theorem.

It didn't turn out that way,
because Fermat's last theorem
was solved first.

I heard of it, I think, before
it went around the nerdy

blogs, and I thought, well,
we could talk about it on
Numberphile.

But then, it's still not been
checked, so maybe we shouldn't
talk about it on Numberphile.

But then when all the blocks
started going mad about it, I
thought someone might ask us.

I mean, that's how you probe
extra dimensions.

That's how you probe
the very small.

comments.text:
+TheiLame Usually it's how it's proven that is applicable, not what it 
proves. Everyone "knew" that Fermat's Last Theorem was right before it was 
formally proven, but when it was proven it brought new tools on the table 
for mathematicians to use. Kind of like how NASA's best contributions to 
society were accidental inventions made while trying to go to space; not 
the part where they actually went to space.

I have my doubts that it has any applicable purposes, but hey: you never 
know.  Most conjectures just raise a question to the nature of numbers and 
how they relate to one-another.  Sometimes that comes to use in other 
fields, but most often you'll find that the roles are reversed: to solve 
this conjecture, you need to instill a lot of application of other 
mathematical building blocks.

comments.author: TheiLame

comments.text:
The conjecture compares the radical of the ordered triplet with the third 
value, though.  Take the sum 88 + 37 = 125.  First of all, let's just put 
this in the form of an ordered triplet: (88, 37, 125).  The conjecture 
would compare 125 with rad(88, 37, 125).  What is rad(88, 37, 125)?  Well, 
let's rewrite all the numbers as the products of primes:

88 + 37 = 125 --> (11 + 2^3) + 37 = (5^3)

The radical of this triplet is the product of the prime factors without 
repetition.  So, in this instance, it would be 11 * 2 * 37 * 5 = 4070.  So 
rad(88, 37, 125) = 4070.  This is greater than the third value of the 
ordered triplet.  The conjecture doesn't compare A or B with C, it compares 
rad(ABC) with C.
comments.author: Arbitrary Renaissance

comments.text:
So, okay, I don't know if I'm missing something or what.  But the way I'm 
seeing it is, you're saying { rad(abc) > c } has infinite exceptions, but { 
rad(abc)^1.0000001 > c } (or any power >1) has finite exceptions.  But what 
cases could make { rad(abc) > c } false, while an infinitesimal increase of 
rad(abc) would make it true?  The way I see it, that would mean that 
rad(abc) = c.  So if I understand correctly, what you're saying is, there 
are infinite cases of { rad(abc) = c } being true, but only finite cases of 
{ rad(abc) > c }.

Am I incorrect somewhere?﻿

comments.author: TerrAkon3000

comments.text:
+Aryan Arora All the conjecture states is this (informally): The 
proportional difference between the radical of a coprime triplet of 
integers and the "c" become arbitrarily small. Given three huge numbers, 
the radical ends up being really (like extremely) close to c an infinite 
number of times. However, If you were to exponentiate the radical by 1.1, 
that will cause the really big radicals that were really close to c to go 
overboard. These are huge numbers we are talking about, even a small power 
can increase a number's size by like 20 digits because of the size of these 
numbers.
comments.author: Nicholas Pipitone

comments.author: Aryan Arora

comments.text:
Ok ok, so I finally got around to watching this again, and got a LITTLE 
more clarity this time... So let me see if I get it better now.  I do see 
now, that obviously rad(abc) could never = c.
But anyway, for k=1, there are infinitely many exceptions.  For any 
particular one of these exceptions to become true (a non-exception), 
rad(abc) has to increase by at LEAST 2, because we're dealing with integers 
and it has to go from less than c, to greater than c.  So that's why you 
can't just increase it by an extremely small number; rather, you have to 
take it to a SLIGHTLY higher power.  But for the extremely high values of 
rad(abc), this slight increase in power is enough to push it over the top.  
It doesn't push ALL exceptions over c, of course, but apparently it pushes 
infinitely many of them over.  Which is very surprising, and that seems to 
be what the idea is.
comments.author: Ace Diamond

comments.author: Aryan Arora

comments.text:
+Aryan Arora As for the real number system: dx is not a real number either 
— most people wouldn't even call it a number. (The "formal," "rigorous" way 
to do calculus has to do with things called "epsilon-delta proofs," which 
remove all mention of infinitesimals and infinities from the premises.) 
(The fact that there are no infinitesimals is called the Archimedean 
property.)

Where did I say that rad(abc)^k=c? I said that rad(abc) *almost equals* c 
(for all but finitely many abc), in the sense that changing the exponent 
from 1 to 1.000001 makes it go over. In other words, rad(abc)<c, but 
rad(abc)^1.000001>c. This happens for all but finitely many c.

rad(abc) was much smaller than c in the video's example because the numbers 
were so small. If a, b, and c were a lot larger, than rad(abc) wouldn't be 
"much much smaller than c."
comments.author: columbus8myhw

comments.text:
+columbus8myhw and u are also wrong in the second para, rad(abc)^k is not 
equalling c, (for k=1,1.00001, 97 etc.)  it is not even remotely close to 
c, thats what i told ace diamond too, look at the examples james gave @ 3:37 
and @ 3:59 , the exception case (3:59) has rad(abc)  much much smaller than 
c i.e rad(abc) < c, and the normal case (3:37) has rad(abc) much larger 
than c i.e rad(abc) > c , rad(abc) can never-ever be equal to c (or cannot 
be almost exactly equal to c) i.e rad(abc) = c is NOT true, for the reason 
of this, see the comment i gave to ace diamond.
comments.author: Aryan Arora

comments.text:
+columbus8myhw u are wrong in the first paragraph, the real number system 
contains every number there is (including infinitesimal numbers). although 
there is no number to represent infinitesimal, in the same way there is no 
number to represent infinity. infinitesimal is written in the form of dx, 
i.e infinitesimally small part of x.
comments.author: Aryan Arora

comments.text:
Well, the thing is, you can't increase it by an infinitesimal amount. 
1.000001 is technically not infinitesimals. (There are no infinitesimal 
numbers in the real number system, or the complex number system either. You 
can make up a number system with infinitesimals, but that's another matter.)

In any case, the idea is that: While there are an infinite number of 
exceptions with k=1, most of these are so very very close to having 
rad(abc) equalling c (without being exactly equal), that having k=1.000001 
makes most of these go over. Of course, if k was even closer to 1 — say, 
1.0000000000001 — there would be *more* exceptions than 1.000001 (since 
fewer would go over); if k was even smaller, there would be even more 
exceptions. And when k is 1, the number of exceptions goes to infinity.
comments.author: columbus8myhw

comments.text:
Yes, an infinitesimal increase is no increase at all. An infinite number of 
infinitesimals does create a finite number, but a finite number of 
infinitesimals has a value of zero (which has been proven, the first part 
in integration, the second by decimal-to-fraction conversions). The 
conjecture would only have a finite number of exceptions if the part added 
to one isn't infinitesimal.

comments.text:
+Gytax0 I think the question is really - what is a number, any number, 
anyway when separated from the object that it counts. Is it something 
objective or a function of language? Why are numbers ruled by abstract 
grammatical categories like case and gender (especially in Platos Greek) 
and does that affect them in any way? Is the difference between una, unus 
and unum etc in for example Latin accidental or substantial? Does a number 
exist when there's no one round to squiggle and count it?
comments.author: Jack Lacan

comments.text:

to some non-integer power will usually yeld a non-integer result but you 
can still compare it to 'c'.

comments.text:
+randomasdf97 Both 99 and 22 have 11 as a factor as does their sum 121 (3^2 
x 11 + 2 x 11 = 11^2). For this to work, none of the numbers in the 
equation may have a common factor, which is why 500 + 461 = 961 works. When 
broken down into prime factors it looks like this: 2^2 x 5^3 + 461 = 31^2.
comments.author: Paul Foor

comments.text:
+Paul Foor lol ok then what about 99+22=121. they all have a common divisor 
of 1 and every single a+b=c with a,b,c positive integers will have every 
a,b,c divisible by 1. abc conjecture states we only care about factors 
larger than 1.  
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abc_conjecture
comments.author: randomasdf97

comments.text: +Nathan Richan I'm reasonably sure you did and with any luck, so did I.
comments.author: Paul Foor

comments.text:
+Paul Foor
I've just never seen them listed as example solutions. I get that if you're 
trying to prove the conjecture, you'd want to use more 'extreme' cases with 
lots of primes on one side, and those low-number equations don't really 
accomplish that. I just wasn't sure if I understood the rules correctly or 
not.
comments.author: Nathan Richan

comments.text:
+Nathan Richan I believe they are. The first example (2+3=5) contains only 
prime numbers. The second example (4+7=11) can be broken down to 2^2+7=11. 
Neither example has any common factors through out their respective 
equations.
comments.author: Paul Foor

comments.text:
+Paul Foor
What about any of the primes?
2 + 3 = 5, no factors in common.
Even just using one prime: 4 + 7 = 11, no factors in common.
How come I'm not seeing those solutions anywhere? Are they just too 
obvious, but still correct solutions?
comments.author: Nathan Richan

comments.text:
No factors in common allowed and 1 can be divided into every whole number 
without a remainder, therefore your equation does not work.

comments.text:
What if you take a prime number (c), substract another prime number from it 
(b), and the resulting even number will be a. Then you've got a + b = c and 
a possibly has many factors, while the other two numbers are prime so b and 
c have only one factor. There's a lot of those, just as much as the 
(prime)^x+(prime)^y=(c) series. (:
